poem:
The Cut

The Fed speaks,
in whispers through
the halls of finance.

Numbers fall
like quiet rain,
a promise
seen but unfelt.

Rates slip 
beneath breaths 
and pulses merge
with the silent hands
of clocks.

Jerome leans in,
a shadow,
and the world
muscles forth
another sigh.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The Federal Reserve is about to cut rates … but by how much? Economic moments are often forecast with great certainty, but few will have been as widely expected as an interest rate cut by the US Federal Reserve this week. Analysts have included a reduction in the cost of borrowing by the US central bank in their forecasts for more than a month and investors have placed their bets accordingly. The Fed’s chair, Jerome". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
